body:
Note:
1. This is going to require some follow up work: there are a fair number of uses of `Int` and `Float` within the Rust distribution. In some cases, we may want to replace these with different traits, but that design work is left as a future step.
2. Currently, this is failing to build due to strange staging problems with the inherent `wrapping_add` etc methods.

Update: I've resolved the staging issue. There appears to be a bad interaction between int fallback and inherent impls. In this case adding a single type annotation was enough to solve the problem.

This should probably be investigated separately in a minimal test case.
Could this also handle https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/23454? (it seems they should both be removed?)
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23512) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

Updated, adding `Zero` and `One`, and removing many imports of `Int` along the way.

@alexcrichton I believe this addresses your concerns.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23654) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
A few nits here and there, but otherwise this all looks great to me! r=me with nits updated
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23681) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
Should `is_sign_positive` and `is_sign_negative` be renamed to `is_sign_bit_positive` and `is_sign_bit_negative`? Just adding "sign" does not clarify anything.

> is_positive and is_negative are renamed to is_sign_positive and
> is_sign_negative, in order to address #22985

Hm, do we actually need both? They're strict logical negations of each other, so maybe it could be collapsed/clarified even futher?

@alexcrichton Want to re-review? I've added back the `Step` trait (as unstable), which should pretty clearly be replaced by some other traits in the future.

re: the sign checks, I'm happy to change the name to further clarify, and to drop one of the variants if preferred. e.g., `is_sign_bit_positive` only (though that's a pretty lengthy name...)

:pushpin: Commit f7c2448 has been approved by `alexcrichton`

<!-- @bors r=alexcrichton f7c24480d6845d5368a1c895a6bc30fee3d87b33 -->

Would it be possible to wait a little bit with stabilizing abs()?
I hope it can give my rfc a chance...
https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1017
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23796) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
@aturon, after this lands will there be any way to get the max value of, for example, `c_int`? Previously that could be done using `Int::max_value`, but I'm not seeing an alternative.
@SSheldon you can use `c_int::max_value()` (it already works today) because `c_int` is just a type alias to an integer primitive.
@japaric, oh wow, I could've sworn you couldn't call static methods through a type alias. Thanks!

@bors: r=alexcrichton a680fe3

@pitdicker I will discuss your RFC with the core team, this PR does not preclude the change before 1.0.
